clinical_study.brief_title: Circulating Tumor DNA as Liquid Biopsy in Patients With Stage IV Solid Tumors, a Feasibility Study at MUSC HCC
clinical_study.official_title: Circulating Tumor DNA as Liquid Biopsy in Patients With Stage IV Solid Tumors, a Feasibility Study at MUSC HCC

brief_summary.textblock:
1. To demonstrate the ability to detect specific cancer mutations in ctDNA isolated from plasma of stage IV cancer patients at HCC.
2. To compare, in each patient, ctDNA longitudinal samples through treatment, and when available, with those of primary tumor and metastasis.

detailed_description.textblock: The overall goal of this study is to study circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) in the blood to determine how cancer cells in patients react to treatment. DNA is short for deoxyribonucleic acid. DNA contains information that determines in part the traits, such as eye color, height, or disease risk, that are passed on from parent to child. This reaction will be measured by studying patient blood that will be collected before and during treatment until there is disease progression.

primary_outcome.measure: Detecting specific cancer mutations in ctDNA isolated from plasma of stage IV cancer patients at HCC.
Changes in patients' ctDNA longitudinal samples through treatment, and when available, of primary tumor and metastasis.

arm_group.description: adult patients with stage IV cancer that are starting a new line of treatment

intervention.description: Twenty-five mL of peripheral blood (PB) will be collected for research. Blood will be collected in EDTA tubes and used to isolate ctDNA. For each subject we will request that he/she contribute 25 mL of plasma no more frequently than every 6 weeks, and at same time of standard of care blood draws and routine clinic visit, and for no more than 5 times (including baseline and end of study).

biospec_descr.textblock: circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) in the blood

study_pop.textblock: Adult patients with stage IV cancer that start a new line of treatment and agree to have blood drawn
